paragraph.content: if the Authority is of the opinion that it is no longer necessary for such a requirement to continue in force—rescind the requirement.

section.name: s95ZT
section.heading: Direction for company to be managed by supervisory manager

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 95ZN(3), the Authority may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a direction that, during the period for which the direction is in force, the affairs, business and property of the designated insurance holding company specified in the direction (including the exercise of the company’s control or influence over any other member of its supervised group) is to be managed by a supervisory manager appointed by the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of paragraph (a), appoint any person as the supervisory manager of the company.

subsection.leadIn: A direction under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be given in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be served on the designated insurance holding company specified in the direction;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: takes effect immediately when it is so served; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must state the name and address of the supervisory manager appointed.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must cause notice of the direction to be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in another way as the Authority considers expedient for notifying the public.

subsection.content: The Authority may give notice of the direction to any involved supervisor of the supervised group of the designated insurance holding company.

section.name: s95ZU
section.heading: Restriction on meetings when direction given under section 95ZT in force

subsection.leadIn: During the period for which a direction given under section 95ZT in relation to a designated insurance holding company is in force—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no meeting of the company may be held except with the consent, and in the presence, of the supervisory manager of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no resolution may be passed at a meeting of the company except with the consent of the manager.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any resolution passed, or purporting to have been passed, in contravention of that subsection is invalid; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: anything done in reliance on any such resolution is also invalid.

subsection.content: If a member or director of a designated insurance holding company requests the supervisory manager of the company to give a consent mentioned in subsection (1)(a), the manager must not unreasonably refuse to give that consent.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: meeting (會議), in relation to a designated insurance holding company, means—(a)a general meeting of the members of the company; or(b)a meeting of the directors of the company.

section.name: s95ZV
section.heading: Powers of supervisory manager

subsection.leadIn: The supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may do anything that is necessary for the management of the affairs, business and property of the company (including the exercise of the company’s control or influence over any other member of its supervised group); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without limiting paragraph (a), may exercise any power specified in Schedule 7A in relation to the company.

subsection.leadIn: The supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company may require any of the persons specified in subsection (3) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: submit any information in relation to the affairs, business and property of the company that the manager reasonably requires for performing the manager’s functions or exercising the manager’s powers in relation to the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: submit such information within the period and in the way specified by the manager.

subsection.leadIn: The persons specified for subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who has ceased to be a chief executive, director or key person in control functions of the designated insurance holding company during the period for which a direction given under section 95ZT is in force; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a shareholder controller of the designated insurance holding company.

subsection.leadIn: The supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company may, with the approval of the Authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remove any chief executive or key person in control functions of the company (whether appointed by the company or the manager); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: appoint any person to be a chief executive, director or key person in control functions of the company.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to an appointment under subsection (4)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sections 95S and 95U do not apply;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 95V applies as if the appointment were an appointment approved under section 95U; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the approval of the Authority mentioned in subsection (4) is not otherwise to be regarded as an approval under section 95U.

subsection.content: The supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company may call any meeting of the members, directors or creditors of the company.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (8) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a designated insurance holding company has a holding company (parent company); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is a chief executive or director of the designated insurance holding company also occupies an equivalent position in the parent company.

subsection.leadIn: The supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company may require a person mentioned in subsection (7)(b) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take all necessary steps within the powers of the person’s position in the parent company to call any meeting of the members, directors or creditors of the parent company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: allow the manager to attend the meeting.

subsection.leadIn: During the period for which a direction given under section 95ZT in relation to a designated insurance holding company is in force—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any power conferred on the company, or its officers or members, that could interfere with the exercise of any power of the supervisory manager of the company is not exercisable except with the consent of the manager; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the manager may give a consent for the purposes of paragraph (a) either generally or in a particular case.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (9)(a), it does not matter whether the power is conferred on the designated insurance holding company, or its officers or members, by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the articles of association of the company.

subsection.leadIn: Where a power of the supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company is exercised—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manager is taken to be acting as an agent of the company in exercising the power; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: insofar as the exercise of the power is concerned, section 9 of the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance (Cap. 201) applies to the following persons as if subsections (4) and (5) of that section were omitted—

subparagraph.content: the manager acting as such an agent; and
any person who offers an advantage within the meaning of that Ordinance to the manager acting as such an agent.

subsection.content: A person dealing with the supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company in good faith and for value is not concerned to inquire whether the manager is acting within the manager’s powers in relation to the company.

section.name: s95ZW
section.heading: Remuneration and expenses of supervisory manager

subsection.content: The Authority may determine the remuneration and expenses to be paid by a designated insurance holding company to the supervisory manager of the company.

subsection.leadIn: If the Authority has made a determination under subsection (1), the Authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: publish a notice in the Gazette stating—

subparagraph.content: that the determination has been made; and
the name of the designated insurance holding company to which the determination relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide a copy of the determination to any member of the company who requests it.

subsection.leadIn: Any remuneration and expenses required by a determination under subsection (1) to be paid by a designated insurance holding company to a supervisory manager—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: are recoverable by the manager as a civil debt; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: have the following priority in a winding up of the company under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32)—

subparagraph.content: for a voluntary winding up—the same priority as the priority given under section 256 of that Ordinance to the remuneration of a liquidator; or

for a winding up by the Court of First Instance—the same priority as the priority given under rule 179(1) of the Companies (Winding-up) Rules (Cap. 32 sub. leg. H) to any costs, charges and expenses incurred by the Official Receiver.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: supervisory manager (監管經理) includes a former supervisory manager.

section.name: s95ZX
section.heading: Revocation of direction given under section 95ZT

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must revoke a direction given under section 95ZT in relation to a designated insurance holding company if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority is satisfied that the situation concerning the company or its supervised group (as mentioned in section 95ZN(3)(a)) that was the basis on which the direction was given has ceased to exist; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is necessary to do so to give effect to a determination of the Tribunal in a review of the Authority’s direction.

subsection.leadIn: The revocation under subsection (1) of a direction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must be served on—

subparagraph.content: the designated insurance holding company specified in the direction; and
the supervisory manager of the company; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: takes effect immediately when it is so served.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must cause notice of the revocation to be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in another way as the Authority considers expedient for notifying the public.

subsection.content: The Authority may give notice of the revocation to any involved supervisor of the supervised group of the designated insurance holding company.

section.name: s95ZY
section.heading: Offences in relation to Part XIA, Division 8

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: acts, or continues to act, as a chief executive or key person in control functions of a designated insurance holding company despite the person having been removed by the supervisory manager of the company from that position under section 95ZV(4)(a);

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.leadIn: wilfully obstructs, resists or delays—

subparagraph.content: the supervisory manager of a designated insurance holding company in lawfully performing the manager’s functions or lawfully exercising the manager’s powers in relation to the company; or
any other person lawfully assisting the manager in such performance of functions or exercise of powers.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction on indictment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a continuing offence under subsection (1)(a)—to a further fine of $1,000 for every day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, in purported compliance with a requirement imposed under section 95ZO—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provides any information, or produces any document, that the person knows to be false or misleading in a material particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly provides any information, or produces any document, that is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s95ZZ
section.heading: Defences in relation to offences under section 95ZY

subsection.content: Subsection (2) applies if an individual is charged by virtue of section 124 with an offence under section 95ZY(1)(a) for the failure by a designated insurance holding company to comply with a requirement imposed under section 95ZO(1) to provide any information, or produce any document, that relates to a member of the supervised group of the company.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for an individual mentioned in subsection (1) to prove that, at the time of the alleged offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information or document was not in the possession or control of the designated insurance holding company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the individual had taken all reasonable steps within the powers of the person’s position in the company to procure—

subparagraph.content: the compliance by the company with the requirement imposed under section 95ZO(1).

subsection.content: Subsection (4) applies if a designated insurance holding company is charged with an offence under section 95ZY(1)(a) for failing to comply with a requirement imposed under section 95ZO(1) to provide any information, or produce any document, that relates to another member of its supervised group.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (3) to prove that, at the time of the alleged offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the information or document was not in the possession or control of the company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company had taken all reasonable steps to exercise the company’s control or influence in relation to the member to procure the provision of the information or document by the member to the company.

subsection.content: Subsection (6) applies if a designated insurance holding company is charged with an offence under section 95ZY(1)(a) for failing to comply with a requirement imposed under section 95ZQ(2) or 95ZR(1) to ensure a matter in relation to another member of its supervised group.

It is a defence for a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (5) to prove that, at the time of the alleged offence, the company had taken all reasonable steps to exercise the company’s control or influence in relation to the member to procure the matter.

It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under section 95ZY(1)(c) to prove that, at the time of the alleged offence, the person had a reasonable excuse for failing to comply with the requirement concerned.

division.name: D9
division.heading: Winding Up of Designated Insurance Holding Company

section.name: s95ZZA
section.heading: Interpretation of Part XIA, Division 9
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: winding up (清盤) means winding up in accordance with Cap. 32.

section.name: s95ZZB
section.heading: Winding up on petition by Authority or others

subsection.content: This section applies if a designated insurance holding company is a company that may be wound up by the Court of First Instance under Cap. 32.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may present a petition for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company on the ground that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company is unable to pay its debts within the meaning of sections 177 and 178 or section 327 of Cap. 32; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company has failed to satisfy an obligation to which it is or was subject by virtue of this Part.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings on a petition presented under subsection (2) for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company, evidence that the company was insolvent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the end of the period to which the specified financial statements of the financial reporting member for its supervised group that were last deposited under section 95ZH(3) relate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on any date or at any time specified in a requirement imposed under section 95ZO,

subsection.continued: is, unless the contrary is proved, evidence that the company continues to be unable to pay its debts.

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may also present a petition for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it appears to the Authority that it is expedient to the interests of the policy holders of the supervised group of the company that the company should be wound up; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company is not already being wound up by the Court of First Instance.

subsection.content: On a petition presented under subsection (4) for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company, the Court of First Instance may wind up the company if the Court thinks it just and equitable for the company to be wound up by the Court.

subsection.leadIn: If a petition for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company is presented by a person other than the Authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the petition must be served on the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Authority is entitled—

subparagraph.content: to be heard on the petition;
to call, examine and cross-examine any witness; and
if the Authority considers it appropriate, to support or oppose the making of a winding-up order.

section.name: s95ZZC
section.heading: Voluntary winding up

subsection.content: A designated insurance holding company may be wound up voluntarily only if permitted by an order of the Court of First Instance.
An order may be made under this section only if notice of the application for the order has been served on the Authority.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to an application for an order under this section, the Authority is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be heard on the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to call, examine and cross-examine any witness; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the Authority considers it appropriate, to support or oppose the making of the order.

section.name: s95ZZD
section.heading: Winding up where direction given under section 95ZT in force

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a petition for the winding up of a designated insurance holding company is presented, whether by the Authority or another person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority has given a direction under section 95ZT in relation to the company before the petition is presented;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the direction has continued in force at all times until the petition is presented; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a winding-up order is made as a result of the petition.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the following provisions of Cap. 32, the winding up of a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (1) is, despite section 184(2) of Cap. 32, taken to have commenced at the time when the direction was given under section 95ZT—
Subsection (4) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the Authority has given a direction under section 95ZT in relation to the company before the application is made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the direction has continued in force at all times until the application is made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an order under section 95ZZC is made as a result of the application.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the following provisions of Cap. 32, the voluntary winding up of a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (3) is, despite section 230 of Cap. 32, taken to have commenced at the time when the direction was given under section 95ZT—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sections 170, 232, 266B, 267A, 269 and 274; and

subsection.content: For the purposes of anything done or suffered to be done by a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (1) or (3) before the commencement date* of the 2016 Amendment Ordinance, subsection (2) or (4) (as the case may be) applies as if the reference to section 266B of Cap. 32 in that subsection were a reference to section 266 of the pre-amended Cap. 32.

For the purposes of a charge created on the undertaking or property of a designated insurance holding company mentioned in subsection (1) or (3) before the commencement date* of the 2016 Amendment Ordinance, subsection (2) or (4) (as the case may be) applies as if the reference to section 267A of Cap. 32 in that subsection were a reference to section 267 of the pre-amended Cap. 32.

Sections 182 and 232 of Cap. 32 do not invalidate any disposition of the property of a designated insurance holding company made by, or under the direction of, the supervisory manager of the company acting in good faith in the course of managing the affairs, business and property of the company.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: pre-amended Cap. 32 (《原有第32章》) means Cap. 32 as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the 2016 Amendment Ordinance.

section.name: s95ZZE
section.heading: Power to conduct inspection

subsection.leadIn: An inspector may exercise the powers under subsections (2) and (3) for ascertaining whether a designated insurance holding company is complying with, has complied with, or is likely to be able to comply with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice or requirement given or imposed under this Part; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a condition imposed under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: At any reasonable time, an inspector—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: may inspect, and may make copies or otherwise record details of, a business record of any member of the group; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: may make inquiries to the company (or a specified person for the company)—

subparagraph.content: concerning a business record of any member of the group; or
concerning a transaction or activity that was undertaken in the course of, or may affect, the business conducted by any member of the group.

subsection.leadIn: In exercising a power under subsection (2)(b) or (c), an inspector may require the designated insurance holding company (or a specified person for the company)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to give the inspector access to a business record of any member of the supervised group of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to produce to the inspector, within the time and at the place specified in the requirement, a business record of any member of the group; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: to answer a question concerning—

subparagraph.content: a business record of any member of the group; or
a transaction or activity that was undertaken in the course of, or may affect, the business conducted by any member of the group.

subsection.content: A requirement imposed under subsection (3) on a designated insurance holding company may also include a requirement for the company to ensure the doing of an act mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of that subsection by another member of its supervised group.

The power under subsection (2)(c) or (3) is not exercisable in relation to a specified person for a designated insurance holding company unless the inspector has reasonable cause to believe that the information or record being sought cannot be obtained by exercising the power in relation to the company.
The Authority may in writing appoint a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, as an inspector for the purposes of this section.
The Authority must provide an inspector with a copy of its appointment.
When imposing a requirement on a person under subsection (3), an inspector must, if so requested, produce a copy of the Authority’s appointment to that person for inspection as soon as practicable.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified person (指明人士), in relation to a designated insurance holding company, means a person whom an inspector has reasonable cause to believe has information relating to, or is in possession of, a business record of any member of the supervised group of the company.

section.name: s95ZZF
section.heading: Inspector may require answer to be verified by statutory declaration

subsection.content: If a person gives an answer to an inquiry made under section 95ZZE(2)(c), or gives an answer in compliance with a requirement imposed under section 95ZZE(3), the inspector may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, the answer by a statutory declaration.

If a person does not give an answer to an inquiry made under section 95ZZE(2)(c), or does not give an answer in compliance with a requirement imposed under section 95ZZE(3), for the reason that the information concerned was not within the person’s knowledge or possession, the inspector may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, by a statutory declaration, that the person did not comply with the requirement for that reason.
A statutory declaration under subsection (1) or (2) may be made before the inspector and, for that purpose, the inspector is to have full power to administer the statutory declaration.

section.name: s95ZZG
section.heading: Power to conduct investigation

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the Authority has reasonable cause to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: this Part may have been contravened;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any member of the supervised group of a designated insurance holding company has carried on, or is carrying on, insurance business in a manner that is not in the interests of policy holders or potential policy holders of the group or the public interest, and the governance framework of the group has failed to prevent this; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person is, or was, not a fit and proper person as described in section 95ZZS(1)(c).

subsection.content: The Authority may, in writing, direct one or more of its employees, or, with the consent of the Financial Secretary, appoint one or more other persons, to investigate the matter described in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c) or (d).
The costs and expenses incurred by an investigator, other than an employee of the Authority, may be paid out of moneys provided by the Legislative Council.
The Authority must provide an investigator with a copy of its direction or appointment.
Before first imposing a requirement on a person under subsection (6), an investigator must produce a copy of the Authority’s direction or appointment to that person for inspection.

subsection.leadIn: An investigator may require a specified person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to produce, within the time and at the place the investigator requires in writing, a specified record or document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to give an explanation or further particulars in respect of a record or document produced;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: to answer in writing, within the time the investigator requires in writing, a written question relating to any matter under investigation that may be raised by the investigator; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to give the investigator all other assistance in connection with the investigation that the person is able to give.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified record or document (指明紀錄或文件), in relation to a specified person, means a record or document specified by the investigator that is or may be relevant to the investigation and is—(a)if the person is a designated insurance holding company—in the possession, control or custody of any member of its supervised group; or(b)in any other case—in the person’s possession.

section.name: s95ZZH
section.heading: Investigator may require explanation etc. to be verified by statutory declaration

subsection.content: If a person gives any explanation, particulars or answer in compliance with a requirement imposed under section 95ZZG(6), the investigator may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, the explanation, particulars or answer by a statutory declaration.

If a person does not give any explanation, particulars or answer in compliance with a requirement imposed under section 95ZZG(6) for the reason that the information concerned was not within the person’s knowledge or possession, the investigator may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, by a statutory declaration, that the person did not comply with the requirement for that reason.
A statutory declaration under subsection (1) or (2) may be made before the investigator and, for that purpose, the investigator is to have full power to administer the statutory declaration.

section.name: s95ZZI
section.heading: Application to Court of First Instance for inquiry into failure

subsection.content: If a person fails to comply with a requirement imposed by an inspector under section 95ZZE or 95ZZF or an investigator under section 95ZZG or 95ZZH, the inspector or investigator may apply by originating summons to the Court of First Instance for an inquiry into the failure.

subsection.leadIn: On an application under subsection (1), the Court of First Instance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on being satisfied that there is no reasonable excuse for the person not to comply with the requirement, may order the person to comply with the requirement within the time specified by the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on being satisfied that the failure was without reasonable excuse, may punish the person, and any other person knowingly involved in the failure, in the same manner as if the person and that other person had been guilty of contempt of court.

subsection.content: An originating summons under subsection (1) is to be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A to the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).

subsection.leadIn: Despite anything in this Ordinance, no proceedings may be instituted against a person for subsection (2)(b) in respect of a conduct if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: criminal proceedings have previously been instituted against the person under section 95ZZJ(1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) in respect of the same conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those proceedings remain pending, or because of the previous institution of those proceedings, no criminal proceedings may again be lawfully instituted against that person under section 95ZZJ(1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) in respect of the same conduct.

section.name: s95ZZJ
section.heading: Offences in relation to inspections and investigations

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a specified requirement imposed on the person.
A person commits an offence if the person, with intent to defraud, fails to comply with a specified requirement imposed on the person.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in purported compliance with a specified requirement imposed on the person, the person produces a record or document, gives an answer, or gives any explanation or particulars, that are false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the record or document, the answer, or the explanation or particulars, are false or misleading in the material particular.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if, in purported compliance with a specified requirement imposed on the person, the person, with intent to defraud, produces a record or document, gives an answer, or gives any explanation or particulars, that are false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, with intent to defraud—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: causes or allows another person to fail to comply with a specified requirement imposed on that other person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: causes or allows that other person, in purported compliance with a specified requirement imposed on that other person, to produce a record or document, to give an answer, or to give any explanation or particulars, that are false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with a requirement imposed on the person under section 95ZZG(6) or 95ZZH(1) only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

subsection.leadIn: Despite anything in this Ordinance, no criminal proceedings may be instituted against a person under subsection (1), (2), (3), (4) or (5) in respect of a conduct if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings have previously been instituted against the person under section 95ZZI(2)(b) in respect of the same conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those proceedings remain pending, or because of the previous institution of those proceedings, no proceedings may again be lawfully instituted against that person under section 95ZZI(2)(b) in respect of the same conduct.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (2), (4) or (5) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified requirement (指明要求) means a requirement imposed under section 95ZZE(3), 95ZZF(1) or (2), 95ZZG(6) or 95ZZH(1) or (2).

section.name: s95ZZK
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.content: If an investigator requires a person to give an answer to a question or to give an explanation or further particulars under this Division, the investigator must ensure that the person has first been informed of the effect of subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: Despite anything in this Ordinance and subject to subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if an investigator requires a person to give an answer to a question or to give an explanation or further particulars under this Division; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the answer, or the explanation or further particulars, might tend to incriminate the person and the person so claims before giving the answer or giving the explanation or further particulars,

subsection.continued: the requirement and the question and answer, or the explanation or further particulars, are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not apply to criminal proceedings in which the person is, in relation to the answer, or the explanation or further particulars, charged with—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: perjury.

section.name: s95ZZL
section.heading: Offences in relation to destruction of records and documents

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person destroys, falsifies, conceals or otherwise disposes of, or causes or permits the destruction, falsification, concealment or disposal of, a record or document that the person is required by an inspector or investigator to produce under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person does so with intent to conceal, from the inspector or investigator, facts or matters capable of being disclosed by the record or document.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s95ZZM
section.heading: Order to pay costs of investigation

subsection.leadIn: If a person is convicted by a court on a prosecution instituted as a result of the findings of an investigation under section 95ZZG—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the court may order the person to pay to the Authority the whole or a part of the costs and expenses of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Authority may recover the whole or that part of the costs and expenses as a civil debt due to it.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority receives an amount under an order made under subsection (1) in respect of any of the costs and expenses of an investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all or any of the costs and expenses have already been paid out of moneys provided by the Legislative Council.

subsection.content: The Authority must pay to the Financial Secretary the amount received under the order to the extent to which it has already been paid out of moneys provided by the Legislative Council.

section.name: s95ZZN
section.heading: Magistrate’s warrants to enter premises etc.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) applies if a magistrate is satisfied on information on oath laid by a person specified in subsection (3) that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there is, or is likely to be, on premises specified in the information a record or document that may be required to be produced under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG.

subsection.leadIn: The magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing a person mentioned in the warrant, and other persons who may be necessary to assist in the execution of the warrant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enter the premises, if necessary by force, at any time within the period of 7 days beginning on the date of the warrant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to search for, seize and remove a record or document that the person mentioned in the warrant has reasonable cause to believe may be required to be produced under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG.

subsection.leadIn: The person specified for subsection (1) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a record or document that may be required to be produced under section 95ZZE—an inspector; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a record or document that may be required to be produced under section 95ZZG—an investigator.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized person has reasonable cause to believe that a person found on the premises is employed, or engaged to provide a service, in connection with a business that is or has been conducted on the premises, the authorized person may require that person to produce for examination a record or document that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is in the possession of that person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the authorized person has reasonable cause to believe may be required to be produced under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized person may, in relation to a record or document required to be produced under subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: prohibit a person found on the premises from—

subparagraph.content: removing the record or document from the premises;
erasing anything from, adding anything to, or otherwise altering anything in, the record or document; or
otherwise interfering in any way with, or causing or permitting any other person to interfere with, the record or document; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: take any other step that appears to the authorized person to be necessary for—

subparagraph.content: preserving the record or document; or
preventing interference with the record or document.

subsection.content: An authorized person who enters any premises under this section must, if required, produce the warrant for inspection.

Section 102 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) applies to any property that has, because of this section, come into the possession of the Authority, as it applies to property that has come into the possession of the police.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement or prohibition imposed on the person under subsection (4) or (5); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: obstructs an authorized person exercising a power conferred by subsection (4) or (5).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (8) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: authorized person (獲授權人) means a person mentioned in, and authorized by, a warrant issued under subsection (2) to carry out the acts set out in paragraphs (a) and (b) of that subsection.

section.name: s95ZZO
section.heading: Removal of records and documents under section 95ZZN

subsection.leadIn: A record or document removed under section 95ZZN(2) may be retained—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a period not exceeding 6 months beginning on the date of its removal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a longer period that may be required because of any criminal proceedings, or any proceedings under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: If an authorized person removes a record or document under section 95ZZN(2), the authorized person must, as soon as practicable after the removal, give a receipt for the record or document.

subdivision.name: SD3
subdivision.heading: Miscellaneous Provisions for Inspection and Investigation

section.name: s95ZZP
section.heading: Lien claimed on records or documents
section.leadIn: If the person in possession of a record or document required to be produced under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG claims a lien on the record or document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the requirement to produce the record or document is not affected by the lien;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no fee is payable for the production; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the production is without prejudice to the lien.

section.name: s95ZZQ
section.heading: Production of information in information systems etc.
section.leadIn: If any information or matter contained in a record or document required to be produced under section 95ZZE or 95ZZG is recorded otherwise than in a legible form, a power to require the production of the record or document includes the power to require the production of a reproduction of the recording of the information or matter or of the relevant part of it—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the recording enables the information or matter to be reproduced in a legible form—in a legible form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the information or matter is recorded in an information system—in a form which enables the information or matter to be reproduced in a legible form.

section.name: s95ZZR
section.heading: Inspection of records or documents seized etc.

subsection.content: If a specified person has taken possession of a record or document under this Division, the specified person must permit a person who would be entitled to inspect the record or document had the specified person not taken possession of it, to inspect it and to make copies or otherwise record details of it at all reasonable times.
The permission is subject to any reasonable conditions the specified person imposes.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified person (指明人士) means—(a)an authorized person within the meaning of section 95ZZN; or(b)an investigator.

section.name: s95ZZS
section.heading: Disciplinary action in respect of designated insurance holding companies

subsection.leadIn: The Authority may exercise any of the powers specified in subsection (2) in respect of a designated insurance holding company if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the company is guilty of misconduct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the company was guilty of misconduct; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Authority is of the opinion that—

subparagraph.content: a person who is a shareholder controller of the company, or who holds the position of a chief executive, director or key person in control functions of the company, is not a fit and proper person to be such a controller or hold that position; or

a person who was a shareholder controller of the company, or who held the position of a chief executive, director or key person in control functions of the company, was not a fit and proper person to be such a controller or hold that position.

subsection.leadIn: The following powers are specified for subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to reprimand the designated insurance holding company publicly or privately;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to order the designated insurance holding company to pay a pecuniary penalty not exceeding the amount which is the greater of—

subparagraph.leadIn: 3 times the amount of the profit gained or loss avoided by the company as a result of—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the misconduct of the company; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the conduct of the shareholder controller, chief executive, director or key person in control functions of the company that leads the Authority to form the opinion referred to in subsection (1)(c) in relation to that shareholder controller, chief executive, director or key person in control functions.

subsection.content: If the Authority has exercised its power under subsection (1), it may disclose to the public details of its decision, the reasons for which the decision was made, and any material facts relating to the case.
The Authority, in forming an opinion for subsection (1)(c), may, among other matters (including those specified in section 95Y), take into account the present or past conduct of the person.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: misconduct (不當行為) means—(a)a contravention of this Part; or(b)a contravention of a condition imposed under this Part,and guilty of misconduct (犯不當行為) is to be construed accordingly.

section.name: s95ZZT
section.heading: Procedural requirements in respect of exercise of powers under section 95ZZS

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must not exercise a power under section 95ZZS without first giving the designated insurance holding company in respect of which the power is to be exercised a reasonable opportunity to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make written representations to the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the company so requests, make oral representations to a person appointed for that purpose by the Authority.

subsection.content: If the Authority decides to exercise a power under section 95ZZS in respect of a designated insurance holding company, the Authority must inform the company of the decision by a written notice.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement of the reasons for the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time when the decision is to take effect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if applicable, the terms in which the designated insurance holding company is to be reprimanded under the decision; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if applicable, the amount of the pecuniary penalty to be imposed under the decision and the period within which it is required to be paid.

section.name: s95ZZU
section.heading: Guidelines for exercise of power to impose pecuniary penalty under section 95ZZS

subsection.leadIn: The Authority must not exercise a power under section 95ZZS to impose a pecuniary penalty unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it has published, in the Gazette and in any other manner it considers appropriate, guidelines to indicate the way in which it proposes to exercise that power; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in exercising that power, it has had regard to the guidelines so published.

subsection.content: The guidelines are not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s95ZZV
section.heading: General provisions relating to exercise of disciplinary powers

subsection.leadIn: At any time when the Authority is contemplating exercising a power under section 95ZZS in respect of a designated insurance holding company, the Authority may, if it considers it appropriate to do so in the interests of policy holders or potential policy holders of the supervised group or the public interest, by agreement with the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exercise a power that the Authority may exercise in respect of the company under section 95ZZS; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take an additional action that the Authority considers appropriate in the circumstances of the case.

subsection.content: If the Authority exercises a power or takes an additional action under subsection (1), it must comply with section 95ZZT as if that section applied to the power or action, unless the company agrees otherwise.

In reaching a decision under this Subdivision, the Authority may have regard to any information or material in its possession that is relevant to the decision, regardless of how the information or material has come into its possession.

section.name: s95ZZW
section.heading: Order for payment of pecuniary penalty

subsection.content: A designated insurance holding company ordered to pay a pecuniary penalty under section 95ZZS must pay the penalty to the Authority within 30 days, or a longer period that the Authority specifies by notice under section 95ZZT(3)(d), after the order has taken effect.
The Court of First Instance may, on an application of the Authority, register an order to pay a pecuniary penalty made under section 95ZZS in the Court.
On registration, the order is to be regarded as an order of the Court of First Instance made within the civil jurisdiction of the Court for the payment of money.

For making an application under subsection (2), the Authority must produce to the Registrar of the High Court a written notice requesting that the order be registered, together with the original and a copy of the order.
A pecuniary penalty paid to or recovered by the Authority under an order made under section 95ZZS must be paid by the Authority into the general revenue.

section.name: s96
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—

def.name: AffectedPerson
def.leadIn: affected person (當事人)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a specified decision set out in Part 1 of Schedule 9—means—

subparagraph.content: a person who is aggrieved by the decision; or
a person in respect of whom the decision is made; or

paragraph.name: b

def.name: Parties
def.leadIn: parties (各方), in relation to a review, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person making the application for the review;

section.def: review (覆核) means a review of a specified decision by the Tribunal under section 101;

specified decision (指明決定) means a decision specified in column 2 of Part 1, 2 or 3 of Schedule 9 that is made under, or referred to in, the provision of this Ordinance specified in column 3 of that Schedule opposite that decision. (Amended 18 of 2020 s. 13)

section.name: s97
section.heading: Establishment of Tribunal

subsection.content: A tribunal is established with the name of “Insurance Appeals Tribunal” in English and “保險事務上訴審裁處” in Chinese.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal has jurisdiction to, in accordance with this Part and Schedule 10—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: review specified decisions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: hear and determine a question or issue arising out of or in connection with a review.

subsection.content: If the Chief Executive considers it appropriate to do so, the Chief Executive may establish additional tribunals for any reviews.
The provisions of this Ordinance apply, with necessary modifications, to the additional tribunals as they apply to the Tribunal.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Composition of Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: Except as otherwise provided in Schedule 10, the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: consists of a chairperson and 2 other members; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is to be presided over by the chairperson who is to sit with the 2 other members.

subsection.content: A member of the Tribunal (including the chairperson) may be paid, as a fee for his or her service, the amount that the Financial Secretary considers appropriate.
The amount payable under this section is a charge on the general revenue.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Schedule 10 has effect in relation to Tribunal
section.leadIn: Schedule 10 has effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the appointment of members of the Tribunal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the proceedings and sittings of the Tribunal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to the procedural and other matters concerning the Tribunal.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Applications for review of specified decisions

subsection.content: An affected person may, by notice in writing to the Tribunal, apply to the Tribunal for a review of a specified decision within the period ending 21 days after the notice informing the person of the decision has been served.

subsection.leadIn: An application for review—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state the grounds for the application.

subsection.content: The Tribunal must, as soon as practicable after receiving an application for review, send a copy of the application to the Authority.
On an application by an affected person, the Tribunal may by order extend the time within which the application for review may be made under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may only grant an extension—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is satisfied that there is a good cause for granting the extension; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after the affected person and the Authority have been given a reasonable opportunity to be heard.

subsection.content: On making the order, the time within which the application for review may be made is extended accordingly.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Determination of review by Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may determine a review of a specified decision by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confirming, varying or setting aside the decision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remitting the matter to the Authority with directions it considers appropriate.

subsection.content: If a specified decision is set aside, the Tribunal may substitute for the decision another decision it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: If the Tribunal varies, or substitutes another decision for, a specified decision, the decision as varied or the other decision substituting for the specified decision—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be a decision that the Authority had power to make in respect of the review in question;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be more or less onerous than the specified decision; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may be made under the same provision as that under which the specified decision has been made or any other provision of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: In reviewing a specified decision, the Tribunal must give the parties to the review a reasonable opportunity to be heard.
Subject to section 104(3), the standard of proof required to determine any question or issue before the Tribunal is to be the standard of proof applicable to civil proceedings in a court of law.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Powers of Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: Subject to Schedule 10, the Tribunal may, for the purpose of a review, on its own initiative or on the application of a party to the review—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receive and consider any material by way of oral evidence, written statements or documents, whether or not the material would be admissible in a court of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: determine the manner in which any material mentioned in paragraph (a) is received;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing signed by the chairperson of the Tribunal, require a person—

subparagraph.content: to attend before it at any sitting and to give evidence; and
to produce any article, record or document in the person’s possession or control relating to the subject matter of the review;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: administer oaths;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: examine or cause to be examined on oath or otherwise a person attending before it and require the person to answer truthfully any question which the Tribunal considers appropriate for the purpose of the review;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: order a witness to provide evidence for the purpose of the review by affidavit;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: order a person not to publish or otherwise disclose any material the Tribunal receives;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: prohibit the publication or disclosure of any material the Tribunal receives at any sitting, or any part of a sitting, that is held in private;
stay any of the proceedings in the review on any grounds and on any terms and conditions that it considers appropriate having regard to the interests of justice;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: determine the procedure to be followed in the review; and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: exercise other powers or make other orders that may be necessary for or ancillary to the conduct of the review or the carrying out of its functions.

subsection.content: The Tribunal may, with the consent of the parties to a review, determine the review on the basis of written submissions only.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with an order, notice, prohibition or requirement of the Tribunal made, given or imposed under subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disrupts any sitting of the Tribunal or otherwise misbehaves during any sitting of the Tribunal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: having been required by the Tribunal under subsection (1) to attend before the Tribunal, leaves the place where the person’s attendance is so required without the permission of the Tribunal;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: hinders or deters any person from attending before the Tribunal, giving evidence or producing any article, record or document, for the purpose of a review;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: threatens, insults or causes any loss to be suffered by any person who has attended before the Tribunal, on account of that attendance; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: threatens, insults or causes any loss to be suffered by the chairperson, or any other member, of the Tribunal at any time on account of the performance of the chairperson’s or member’s functions.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with an order, notice, prohibition or requirement of the Tribunal made, given or imposed under subsection (1) only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence given for the purpose of review

subsection.content: This section applies to any evidence, answer or information given or provided by a person in accordance with a requirement or order of the Tribunal under section 102(1)(c), (e), (f) or (k).

Despite anything in this Ordinance and subject to subsection (3), neither the evidence, answer or information given or provided by the person nor the requirement or order of the Tribunal is admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law.

Subsection (2) does not apply to criminal proceedings in which the person is charged with an offence under section 102(3)(a), or under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200), or with perjury, in respect of the evidence, answer or information.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Contempt dealt with by Tribunal

subsection.content: The Tribunal has the same powers as the Court of First Instance to punish for contempt.

Without limiting subsection (1), the Tribunal has the same powers as the Court of First Instance to punish for contempt, as if it were contempt of court, a person who, without reasonable excuse, engages in a conduct falling within section 102(3)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e) or (f).
The Tribunal must, in exercising its powers to punish for contempt, adopt the same standard of proof as the Court of First Instance in the exercise of the same powers to punish for contempt.

subsection.leadIn: Despite anything in this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: no power may be exercised under this section to determine whether to punish a person for contempt in respect of any conduct if—

subparagraph.content: criminal proceedings have previously been instituted against the person under section 102(3) in respect of the same conduct; and

those criminal proceedings remain pending or because of the previous institution of those criminal proceedings, no criminal proceedings may again be lawfully instituted against the person under that section in respect of the same conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: no criminal proceedings may be instituted against a person under section 102(3) in respect of any conduct if—

subparagraph.content: any power has previously been exercised under this section to determine whether to punish the person for contempt in respect of the same conduct; and

proceedings arising from the exercise of that power remain pending or because of the previous exercise of that power, no power may again be lawfully exercised under this section to determine whether to punish the person for contempt in respect of the same conduct.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Privileged information
section.content: This Part and Schedule 10 do not require an authorized institution, acting as the banker or financial advisor of the applicant for a review, to disclose information in relation to the affairs of any of its customers other than that applicant.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Costs

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may, in relation to a review, by order award to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person whose attendance, whether or not as a witness, has been necessary or required for the purpose of the review; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a party to the review,

subsection.continued: a sum that it considers appropriate in respect of the costs reasonably incurred by the person or party in relation to the review and the application for the review.

subsection.leadIn: The costs awarded must be paid by, and are recoverable as a civil debt from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if they are awarded to a person under subsection (1)(a)—a party to the review that the Tribunal considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if they are awarded to a party to the review under subsection (1)(b)—the other party to the review.

subsection.content: Subject to a rule made under section 117, Order 62 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) applies to the award of costs, and to the taxation of any costs awarded, by the Tribunal under subsection (1).

section.name: s107
section.heading: Notification of Tribunal determinations

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal must, as soon as practicable after completing a review, notify the parties to the review—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its determination and the reasons for the determination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any order made under section 106 in relation to the review and the reasons for the order.

subsection.leadIn: If a sitting of the Tribunal, or a part of it, is held in private, the Tribunal may by order prohibit the publication or disclosure of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its determination, or the reasons for the determination, referred to in subsection (1)(a), or a part of the determination or reasons; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order, or the reasons for an order, referred to in subsection (1)(b), or a part of the order or any part of the reasons for the order.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with an order of the Tribunal made under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Form and proof of orders of Tribunal

subsection.content: An order made by the Tribunal must be recorded in writing and be signed by the chairperson of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: A document purporting to be an order of the Tribunal so signed is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, presumed to be an order of the Tribunal duly made and signed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without proof of its making;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without proof of signature; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without proof that the person signing the order was in fact the chairperson of the Tribunal.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Orders of Tribunal may be registered in Court of First Instance

subsection.content: After receiving a notice in writing given by the Tribunal in the manner prescribed by rules made under section 117, the Court of First Instance may register an order of the Tribunal in that Court.
An order so registered is to be regarded for all purposes as an order of the Court of First Instance made within its jurisdiction.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Application for stay of execution of specified decisions

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (4), an application for review does not by itself operate as a stay of execution of the specified decision to which the application relates.

A person who applies for a review or an application referred to in section 100(4) may, at any time before the review or the application is determined by the Tribunal, apply to the Tribunal for a stay of execution of the specified decision to which the application relates.
The Tribunal must, as soon as practicable after receiving an application under subsection (2), conduct a hearing to determine the application.
The Tribunal may by order grant the stay subject to a condition as to costs, payment of money into the Tribunal or other matters that the Tribunal considers appropriate.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Applications for stay of execution of determinations of Tribunal

subsection.content: A party to a review may, at any time after the determination of the review by the Tribunal, apply to the Tribunal for a stay of execution of the determination.

On an application under subsection (1), the Tribunal may by order grant the stay subject to a condition as to costs, payment of money into the Tribunal or other matters that the Tribunal considers appropriate.

section.name: s112
section.heading: Appeal to Court of Appeal

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), if a party to a review is dissatisfied with the determination of the review, the party may appeal to the Court of Appeal against the determination on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a question of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a question of fact; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a question of mixed law and fact.

subsection.content: No appeal may be made under subsection (1) unless leave to appeal has been granted by the Court of Appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The leave may be granted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a particular issue arising out of the determination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to a condition that the Court of Appeal considers necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The leave may only be granted if the Court of Appeal is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the appeal should be heard.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Powers of Court of Appeal

subsection.leadIn: The Court of Appeal may, in relation to an appeal against a determination of the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allow the appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dismiss the appeal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vary or set aside the determination and, if the determination is set aside, substitute for the determination another determination that it considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: remit the matter to the Tribunal or to the Authority with any directions it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court of Appeal varies, or substitutes another determination for, a determination under subsection (1)(c), the determination as varied or the other determination substituting for the determination—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be a determination that the Tribunal had power to make in respect of the review in question;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be more or less onerous than the determination varied or substituted; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may be made under the same provision as that under which the determination varied or substituted has been made or any other provision of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: In an appeal under this section, the Court of Appeal may make any order for payment of costs it considers appropriate.

section.name: s114
section.heading: No stay of execution of Tribunal’s determination on appeal

subsection.content: Without prejudice to section 111, the lodging of an appeal under section 112 does not by itself operate as a stay of execution of the determination of the Tribunal appealed against.

If an appeal is lodged under section 112, the Court of Appeal may, on an application made to it by a party to the review, order a stay of execution of the determination of the Tribunal appealed against.

The Court of Appeal may, when making an order under subsection (2), impose a condition that the Court of Appeal considers appropriate, including conditions as to costs and payment of money into the Tribunal.

section.name: s115
section.heading: No other right of appeal
section.content: Subject to section 50 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) and section 112, the determination of the Tribunal is final and is not subject to appeal.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Time when specified decisions take effect

subsection.leadIn: Except as otherwise provided in this Ordinance, a specified decision takes effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if, before the expiry of the period of 21 days specified in section 100, an affected person notifies the Authority in writing that the person will not apply for a review of the decision—at the time the person so notifies the Authority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if, within the period of 21 days specified in section 100, the person does not apply for a review of the decision—at the time the period expires; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the person applies for a review of the decision within the period of 21 days specified in section 100—

subparagraph.content: if the decision is varied, or substituted by another decision, by the Tribunal—at the time the decision is varied or substituted, subject to the terms of the variation or substitution; or
if the application is withdrawn—at the time the application is withdrawn.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1), the Authority may, if it considers it appropriate in the public interest to do so in relation to a specified decision, specify in the notice in respect of the decision any time, other than that at which the decision is apart from this section to take effect, as the time at which the decision is to take effect.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Power of Chief Justice to make rules
section.leadIn: The Chief Justice may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for the award of costs under section 106;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for matters relating to the registration of an order of the Tribunal in the Court of First Instance under section 109;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regulating the procedure for the hearing of appeals under section 112;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: requiring the payment of the fees specified in the rules for a matter relating to applications for review;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: providing for matters of procedure or other matters relating to applications for review, which are not provided for in this Part or in Schedule 10;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: providing for the issue or service of any document (however described) for the purposes of this Part or Schedule 10; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prescribing a matter which this Part provides is, or may be, prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Immunity

subsection.content: A person is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the person in good faith in performing or purportedly performing a function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an auditor appointed under section 5E, 72 or 95ZF; and (Amended 18 of 2020 s. 14)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an auditor or actuary appointed under section 15.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Other Offences and Supplementary Provisions on Offences

section.name: s119
section.heading: Misleading statements, etc. and false information

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person induces or attempts to induce another person to enter into, or offer to enter into, a contract of insurance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a statement, promise or representation which the person knows to be false, misleading or deceptive;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a dishonest concealment of material facts; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by the reckless making (dishonest or otherwise) of a statement, promise or representation which is false, misleading or deceptive.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: causes or permits to be included in a document specified in subsection (3) a statement which the person knows to be false in a material particular; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly causes or permits to be included in a document specified in subsection (3) a statement which is false in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: The document specified for subsection (2) is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a notice or statement or certificate served or furnished or sent out under a provision of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document or copy of a document deposited or submitted under a provision of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s120
section.heading: Restriction on use of certain terms and representations associated with insurance business

subsection.leadIn: Except as provided for in section 123, a person must not, without the written consent of the Authority given generally or in a particular case or class of cases, use any of the following in the description or name under which the person is carrying on business in or from Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the word “insurance” or “assurance”, or a derivative of the word in English, or a translation of the word or derivative in any language;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chinese expression “保險”, or the character “保” followed immediately by the character “險”;

paragraph.name: c
